story.text: LONDON Jan 2 The FTSE 100 .FTSE index of Britain's leading shares rose 1.1 percent on Tuesday to its highest level since February 2001, led by mining company Lonmin (LMI.L) as the sector gained on higher precious metal prices. Lonmin was up 2.3 percent while Anglo-American (AAL.L) rose 2.1 percent and BHP Billiton (BLT.L) gained 1.9 percent. The gold price jumped to its highest in nearly a month as the dollar weakened, prompting investors to build fresh trading positions at the start of the new year, with base metals softer. By 1150 GMT, the FTSE 100 index rose 71.5 points to 6,293.3, its highest level since 6 February 2001, when it reached 6,306.70. Traders said shares lacked direction, with U.S. markets set to remain closed on Tuesday to mark the death of former President Gerald Ford. "This is a good start to the year, ahead of Christmas trading statements out from tomorrow, but it's a strange day and shares may come back when there is no trading in New York this afternoon," said Lawrence Peterman, investment director at Eden Financial. The UK December Purchasing Managers Index, a gauge of British manufacturing, came in at 51.9, compared with 52.5 in November and a forecast 52.6, and was at its lowest since March 2006. The data slightly eased pressure for a short-term interest rate rise, traders said. House prices in England and Wales rose 0.6 percent on the month in November, and 6.8 percent year-on-year, according to Land Registry data. Banks gained on the data because it showed continued growth in the UK housing market, benefiting mortgages, traders said. Alliance & Leicester AL.L rose 2.5 percent and Barclays (BARC.L) gained 2 percent. British-based building and plumbing supplier Wolseley (WOS.L) gained 1.9 percent on related sentiment. Among other standout gainers, Vodafone (VOD.L) rose 2 percent on market talk that the mobile telecoms giant is less likely to acquire Hutchison Essar after the Financial Times reported that India's Essar group, the minority partner in the mobile phone joint venture, has tied up financing for a potential bid for the two thirds of the business it does not own. Former telecoms monopoly BT Group (BT.L) rose 1.8 percent after Goldman Sachs upped its price target on the stock, traders said. Elsewhere, Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus CS.L rose 1.1 percent. Indian newspapers said that Tata Steel (TISC.BO) was in the closing stages of putting in a final bid for Corus, which would raise the stakes in its takeover battle with Brazil's Companhia Siderurgica nacional (CSN) (CSNA3.SA), citing unnamed sources close to the development. Oil giant BP (BP.L) rose 0.6 percent and rival Royal Dutch Shell (RDSa.L) rose 1.3 percent, but they underperformed relative to some European peers. The oil price fell below $61 a barrel, unmoved by strength in other financial markets. British Airways BAY.L rose 2.2 percent on continued sector consolidation talk, traders said. Property companies were mixed after they converted on Monday to real estate investment trust (REIT) status, which gives them a more tax-efficient structure. British Land (BLND.L) rose 0.2 percent after it estimated a one-off REIT conversion charge of 300 million pounds ($589.6 million), and Land Securities (LAND.L) rose 0.2 percent, but Hammerson (HMSO.L) fell 0.4 percent.
story.title: ftse rises , miners strong , lonmin leads
